title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the dollar against the renminbi on 28 April 2017?
preds: Two days to go and the spot is 6.89 and trending slowly upward.

Trump has begun initiating policy to devalue the dollar, but not anything significant enough to drop it down beneath 6.6 renminbi.  As such, it is most likely that the dollar will remain in the 6.6-7.2 range, and unless Trump takes drastic action then it won't be worth less than 6.6 renminbi.  Additionally, Trump would have to significantly strengthen the dollar in order to exceed 7.2 renminbi, which seems unlikely given his rhetoric.
At 6.8861 CNY. Forecast remains in the correct band. Only 9 days left.
The general consensus that I have seen is that it will keep in the 6.6-7.2.  Right now, it is exactly in between the two at 6.9.  It is unlikely that any major changes will be seen.
Shifting nine points to the middle option. I don't imagine there will be major currency shifts in the next few weeks
Reduce uncertainty in favor of center bucket due to passage of time, though upcoming meeting with Chinese leaders could have a minor impact.
Still 3 weeks to go and there's plenty that could cause the spot to shift suddenly, but this is looking more certain by the day; the spot moved from 6.89 to 6.9 in the last couple of days.

6.88 today. Talks with Xi may change it but I am betting all concerned do not want big change. Rhetoric on China has been toned down. Too much money involved so I am betting no trade war. Maybe a photo op action but nothing to rock the boat.
Adjusted each from 10 to 8 - was prob a bit conservative on first prediction.

Affirming forecast. Come on everyone. Look at the 10-year historical trend, easily available on Bloomberg. How often has the exchange rate moved 30 cents in one month? You're giving me free accuracy score.

The US Treasury branding China as a currency manipulator could cause a crash in the yuan, but currently it seems less likely than before.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-29/trump-s-yuan-manipulation-views-don-t-tick-all-treasury-s-boxes

Main determinants of the E/R in the short run:
1) I/R announcements
2) Investors output forecasts
3) The intentions of the Chinese government There isn't going to be another FOMC announcement until May, so we can probably rule out changes in either countries base rate.
Investors seem to be pouring out of gold and risk free assets in response to the positive signals given by the Trump administration (i.e. the expected rate of return in the US has increased), so there is a possibility of increasing demand for Dollars through FDI demand. This might lead to a E/R appreciation.
However, China have historically been very protective over their exchange rate, so I would expect government intervention if the Yuan depreciated/appreciated significantly, meaning the probability of a large change from the current E/R is small.

I took another quick look.  Over the past 17 years there have been 4093 30-day windows and only two of them had a change large enough to push us out of 6.6 to 7.2 window.  Those happened with US debt was downgraded in 2011 ( https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903366504576490841235575386 ) . Snipped of python below to pull data from Yahoo in case useful.
start = datetime.datetime(2000,3,24)
end = datetime.datetime(2017,3,24)
df = web.DataReader('CNY=X', 'yahoo', start, end)
targetPctChange = ( 6.8802 - 6.6 ) / 6.8802
historicalPctChanges = df['Close'].pct_change(30)
num_smaller_periods = (abs(historicalPctChanges[30:]) < targetPctChange).sum()
num_larger_periods = (abs(historicalPctChanges[30:]) >= targetPctChange).sum()
print(num_larger_periods)
print(num_smaller_periods)
Unrest and uncertainty surrounding US president Trump and the White House will also affect the exchange rate with China.

The RMB currently trades at 6.8875 to the USD. In the past 5 years, the PRC has never allowed the RMB to fall more than 0.1 within 1 month. For it to fall by more than 0.2875 is near-zero.  Similarly, for it to exceed 7.2, the RMB would have to climb by 0.3125. Such a large climb has never happened in the past 5 years as well, though it has climbed by more than 0.1/1 month a few times. Given that neither country appears to be on the brink of a massive financial bubble, I do not see any real chance that the RMB will trade outside the current range.
China’s premier seeks to cool trade tensions with US, see Financial Times. There seems to be growing commitment at both sides to avoid too much devaluation of the Renminbi vis-a-vis the dollar
More restrictions on capital outflows by Chinese governments to limit further decline of the Renminbi against the dollar

The Yuan has been in the 6.6 to 7.2 band since June, and that's the sort of consistency that I like to see when making predictions. That being said, my standard guide for currencies, the Economist's Big Mac index, suggests the Yuan may be undervalued by 6.5% as of January 2017 so maybe it will continue its slow (emphasize slow) rise. This is after all a major currency that doesn't move more than a penny or so a day, and that would be extreme movement. http://www.economist.com/content/big-mac-index
Two point adjustment into center bucket.
Adjustment based on current status of exchange rate. Potential problems could come with an announcement concerning interest rates.

Latest IMF reporting has indicated that the Yuan is not currently undervalued.

according to the what the chinese government can do, i predict there should be around 2-3% appreciation/depreciation which is why 6.6 to 7.2 should be the most reasonable.

Changing my prediction based on trends in the exchange rate since the election -- stable between 6.85 and 6.95. There was a run below 6.6 last spring (before mid-June 2016), so it's possible for seasonal trends to move this back by the end of April (no change in the under-6.6 prediction).

Rise of US interest rates will attract capital inflows, also from China and the Chinese government is and will try to lower or block this flow and even take more intervening measures; only in an extreme scenario (e.g. pegging) this may stop the current devaluation trend. As the depreciation continues and exceeds, for example, 7, Trump will announce new measures to stop it, but the effects uncertain and it may take some time before the effects are visible. Since Trump's election the decline has stopped but as things get back to usual (in as far that is possible), the rising trend may return again driven by structural forces (US interest rates, capital inflows).

Last time it was less than 6.6 was last June. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/USDCNY:CUR
It hasn't been above 7.2 in last year and it would not sit well with new US administration. The Hong Kong exchange futures market shows a rising value with max of 7.2 way out at Sept 18.  I have not done enough research to know if this is the most liquid exchange.  https://www.hkex.com.hk/eng/ddp/Contract_Details.asp?PId=220

At the current rate of 6.8665, to be outside the 6.6-7.2 range would require appreciation of 4.04% or depreciation of 4.63% in 68 days. Moves of such magnitude would not be uncommon in most FX markets. However, while since August 2015 there has been greater market input in setting the RMB, ultimately the rate is controlled by the PBoC.  What the US does (whether Trump, Congress or Fed is secondary). The overriding priority will be to avoid a disorderly movement either up or down, and the PBoC clearly still has sufficient foreign exchange reserves to support the currency at least in the near term.
The RMB has been on a declining trend since the beginning of 2014 in large part due to dollar strength (see here for the trade-weighted chart https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TWEXB). Recently, the RMB has been relatively stable against other major currencies (e.g. the euro). The PBoC has been moving its focus away from just the dollar to a basket of currencies. 
Since the unexpected devaluation in August 2015, there have been four declines in the RMB of around 3-4% in any 68 day period. The biggest was 4.17% in January 2016. The time period in which the PBoC's current currency exchange policy has been in place is only relatively short (around 18 months). However, it seems unlikely that in just over the next 2 months the RMB will move outside the central band, even if there is a "surprise" event (e.g. the US declaring China a currency manipulator),  I would estimate a move of such magnitude happening around once every 3 years, i.e. around 6% chance before end April. I think a depreciation is more likely than appreciation, giving the likely continued selling pressure from Chinese investors.

Despite the campaign rhetoric, The renminbi has gotten stronger over last 5 years. China is trying to minimize currency outflows, so needs to take practical steps to keep "R" strong. The curve ball in this is trying to determine when the new US tax policy will be passed by Congress and signed. Initially, it is hard to know how much effect this will have, though the border-adjustment piece supposedly will make $$ stronger. And, the Fed's likely 2-3 rate hikes in 2017 will add strength to the $$. Paradoxically, a strengthened dollar will increase the value of $-denominated debt of foreign countries.
Trump will try to devaluate the US dollar but won't succeed that much.

The PBoC has a large amount of reserves.  While they have been disgorging reserves rapidly to maintain this dirty peg, they still can hold it for many more years.  This alone suggests that China are in no hurry to devalue. Kyle Bass etc speculate China will have to increase their money supply rapidly should a banking crisis occurs.  The prevalence of their shadow banking (WMPs), unproductive infrastructure spending and arguably corruption suggest a crisis is quite probable over the next few years.  Many other 'researchers' support this view. If the PBoC were to allow a relatively rapid or predictable devaluation, it could cause many problems.  Two of these are speculators may push the movement more quickly than they'd like and secondly it may be criticised as being currency 'manipulation' to help their exports. The swap market for offshore Yuan has a much higher yield than the swap market for USD. Based on a no-arbitrage argument, the Yuan should have a tendency depreciate. The US economy is generally considered strong and it is likely that there central bank will continue hiking.  This may not eventuate though should negative economic surprises occur.  This alone would strengthen the Yuan relative to the Dollar.  Many speculators are long the Dollar and such a negative suprise may cause an abrupt move against the dollar. Given all of the above, along with the usual no-arbitrage and Martingale type assumptions, I expect that this exchange rate will continue on approximately the same trajectory in the near term.  Most probable paths lie in the 6.6 to 7.2 region given the current volatility.
That's a lot of change in a short time. I think it's a pretty good bet that it stays in the middle of this range.
Adjustment. Monetary exchange rates are not likely to move very quickly. There is still quite some time, but it goes against previous trends for these two currencies to fluctuate wildly.

Has been very near the middle of the middle bucket for over a month now [1], seemingly unmoved by Trump actions. Saw major rise after US election result but leveled off below 7. So far Trump has not emphasized China, preferring to pick battles closer to home. If anything, seems fairly amicable towards China recently. And China seems to have been "waiting to see" instead of making first moves. Big change on their monetary policy seems unlikely in this climate. Currently, only way for question to resolve outside of middle bucket is for the exchange rate to change by 30 cents in less than 3 months. Eyeballing the 10-year graph [3] this seems to have happened maybe zero or one times in last 10 years (including Great Recession). [1] http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=1M
[2] http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=1Y
[3] http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=USD&to=CNY&view=10Y

Google Finance currently puts CNY at a value of 0.1459 USD (i.e. 6.854 CNY/USD), just below the middle of the range 6.6 - 7.2. The long Dollar trade is THE MOST crowded trade at the moment confirmed by the latest HF position survey. The Yuan weakening trade is the byproduct of the consensus driven strong Dollar trade.  My theory revolves around how fund flows tend to over exaggerate these near-term moves. USD weakening as a result of funds piling out of the crowded trade will see currency pairs across the globe strengthen as a result. Take for example many of the currency pairs that are already strengthening like CAD, EUR, AUD, and JPY. The resulting effect will see Yuan strengthen back below 6.6 in the coming months.
Straight down the middle unless there is economic turmoil.

Right now steady at 6.88. Read Article that Yuan tracks with bitcoin and both should be lower at end of next year. This is a short time so I will stay for now with this. Trade war, war war could upend the current stability.

A lot will depend on whether China will implement capital controls to halt the slide of the renminbi. If not, the self perpetuating depreciation cycle will continue, with the middle classes moving their assets into other currencies. The Chinese central bank could also dump their fx reserves, but they could do that only to a certain extent as they would still need a buffer of USD. Any decrease in the US current account deficit to China should put further downward pressure on the renminbi, but there is unlikely to be too big a change in the deficit by end of April, since a lot of deals settled between now and then have already been agreed upon. In addition, there are two FOMC meetings between now and end of April. The Fed won't raise rates again in January, but may do so in March if the unemployment and especially inflation figures support it. Currently the expectation seems to be that there will be three hikes in 2017, so the first could occur in March. This will further strengthen the USD.

A low renmibi also encourages the flow of capital out of China, which is not in the interest of Chinese government. Hence a status quo around 7.0

The PBOC is currently in the process of stemming the decline in value of the renminbi due to aggressive market flows, overcapacity issues inside of China, increasing geopolitical tensions etc. The decline is likely to be well managed, particularly given the level of reserves the PBOC has but I expect a steady erosion of the value of the renminbi down through towards 7.0 and 7.2. Above 7.2 by April would only occur if the PBOC were to decide not to manage the gradual decline and allow market forces to take over, which is unlikely, given their current and past actions.

Measured against a certain date is impossible to predict.  The battle of the currency will start in earnest shortly after Mr. Trump takes the Oath.  There will be a rash of tweets about China's unfair dealings, pressure on many American companies to move manufacturing out of China and they will capitulate for the public pressure and desire to hate.  The Chinese will struggle for a while to fight Mr. Trumps insinuations as America has not historically used this tactic.  However, they are more versed with this approach than we like to give them credit and they will start to use their significant economic power in the US to cause the US economy to stagnate.  This will tend to cause their currency to rise and they will start stealing markets from American companies who will attempt to reign in Mr. Trump.

USD traded at over 7.2 RMB as recently as 2008, before the Great Recession. The USD has strengthened steadily since 2013 and is back to levels seen in 2010. All major international funds are predicting that China's economy will continue to slow. On the other hand, international markets are uncertain about the affect a Trump presidency will have on the global economy and are pricing it into the value of the USD. If Trump continues irritating its trading partners and initiates a low-level trade war with its partners, the US economy will likely be hurt more in the long run.

Since August 11, 2015 the spot CNY has been on a pace of about 5% annualized depreciation, and recent intervention coincided with the yuan falling over 2% below that pace. That pace implies a 6.93 rate at the end of April 2017, close to the recent level. In addition, Chinese policymakers are mindful of the political ramification of currency weakening during this sensitive period, and recent efforts show a willingness to slow the pace of decline.

Based on analyst predictions on Bloomberg, trend analysis and the probability of a change of exchange rate regime over the period (I´ve assumed a 2% chance).

CNY futures are pricing 17 April 2017 at 1 USD = 7.13 CNY, and 15 May 2017 at 1 USD = 7.15 CNY [1]. Of course it is to be expected that CNY would be cheaper when bought in a farther away futures contract due to time discounting. Let's say we average these and call the 28 April 2017 1 USD  = 7.14 CNY. Let's imagine that on 28 April 2017 we have 1 USD > 7.2 CNY. That would mean a loss of ~0.85% on this investment. This seems well within what investors would consider acceptable losses on a 4-month investment, so it's hard to rule out. On the other hand, if on 28 April 2017 we have 1 USD < 6.6 CNY that would mean a profit of over 8% in 4 months. This seems too high, most investments can only pull that off in a whole year in any reliable way. So below 6.6 seems very unlikely, or rather, judged to be very unlikely by the price-aggregated wisdom of people whose job it is to figure these things out. Anyway, to assign actual odds, let's think about returns. Most investments give around 6%-12% a year reliably. This means roughly 1.5%-3% every four months. Let's imagine investors model returns as a normal distribution [2] with mean 2.25% and standard deviation 1%. Under this model we get no chance of >8% returns and 0.1% chance of <-0.85% returns. This seems too extreme, so let's try a standard deviation of 2%; then we get 0.2% chance of >8% returns and 6% chance of <-0.85% returns. If we do the same exercise but modeling returns as N(3,2) (which I like because currency is a risky investment so the mean had better be higher) we get 0.6% odds of >8% returns and 2.7% odds of <-0.85% returns. Sort of averaging all this I come to my forecast. [1] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/emerging-market/chinese-renminbi.html
[2] http://onlinestatbook.com/2/calculators/normal_dist.html

The dollar has been above 6.6 for the last six months. I believe the Fed's current stance on interest rates makes it HIGHLY unlikely that the dollar would drop in value below that floor. Meanwhile, in order to top 7.2 in the next 120+ days, the dollar would have to rise against the Yuan at at least 77% of the pace of the run-up it has seen in the last 120 days.
